campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Policy priorities include: adequate and equitable investment in transformative public schools, ending the privatization of education, and ending the school-to-prison-and-deportation pipeline","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The campaign works to end discriminatory and oppressive policies that marginalize Black people and other communities of color, particularly in our education and criminal legal systems. CPD looks to strengthen the power of communities to ensure public safety is defined and resourced through investments in education, health, jobs, and housing, rather than in the trillions currently spent on policing and jails. The campaign supports multijurisdictional campaigns for Black freedom including divest/invest, 94 crime bill repeal, ending criminalization/mass incarceration.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Desiree Alliance is a national coalition of current and former sex workers working together with supporting networks for an improved understanding of sexual policies and the human, social, and political impacts of criminalization surrounding global policies in sex work. \n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Reframe Health and Justice Consulting is committed to developing and delivering holistic, harm reduction solutions to social injustices. \n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Probation and Fees Campaign pays up to $1,000 for specific fees related to court fees, substance abuse/DWI classes, anger management classes, court fees, etc. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Center for Resilient Individuals, Families, and Communities; Movement for Black Lives

linkUrl.text: The Center for Resilient Individuals, Families and Communities (CRIFC)

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Harm Reduction Coalition leads policy and advocacy efforts aimed at eliminating the existing disparities that people who use drugs face when it comes to accessing healthcare or basic human services. They are building power with local leaders to address racialized drug policies that put people who use drugs in harm’s way.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Working to expand fair-chance hiring laws, including \"ban the box\" policies across the country\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Developing model school policies for schools, districts, states, and federal policy-makers to avoid criminalization of students. Policies include ending the regular presence of law enforcement in schools and creating safe schools through positive safety and discipline.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Urban Youth Collaborative, The Center for Popular Democracy

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The BREATHE Act offers a reimagining of public safety, community care, and how we spend money as a society. The BREATHE Act proposes to: (1) divest federal resources from incarceration and policing; (2) invest in non-punitive, non-carceral approaches to community safety; (3) allocate new money to build healthy, sustainable, and equitable communities; (4) hold political leaders accountable and enhance the self-determination of all Black communities \n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Padres & Jóvenes Unidos is a multi-issue organization led by people of color who work for educational equity, racial justice, immigrant rights and advocating for equal access to achieve a better quality of life. Their Freedom to Learn framework is based on the belief that education is a right, not a privilege. They believe that all students, regardless of race, income, or immigration status, deserve equal access to high-quality public schools that prepare them for college.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Youth United for Change (YUC) develops young leaders in Philadelphia with a critical political, historical, and economic understanding of society, and empowers them to improve the quality of their lives and communities.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Movement Alliance Project (formerly Media Mobilizing Project) builds power with community organizations working at the intersection of race, technology and inequality. We run strategic campaigns, lift up untold stories, and build infrastructure for poor and working people to win lasting power and a just society.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

linkUrl.text: Movement Alliance Project (formerly Media Mobilizing Project)

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Philadelphia Student Union exists to build the power of young people to demand a high-quality education in the Philadelphia public school system. They are a youth-centered organization and we make positive changes in the short term by learning how to organize to build power. They also work toward becoming life-long learners and leaders who can bring diverse groups of people together to address the problems that their communities face.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"R2C  seeks to elevate the defender voice in criminal justice reform conversations and provides new opportunities for citizens to become engaged advocates, ensuring effective public defense delivery systems in courts across the country.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Justice Programs Office at American University

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Messages Project is a nonprofit organization that enables children of incarcerated parents to maintain and rebuild relationships with their mothers and fathers. Since 1999, The Messages Project has recorded and delivered more than 10,000 video messages from incarcerated parents to their children. Carolyn LeCroy, Founder and CEO of The Messages Project, was named a CNN Hero in 2008 for her efforts and advocacy for these at-risk youth.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.campaignName: Campaign for an Independent Public Defense Commission

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"State leadership understands that the Commission is the way to fix our broken system of public defense, but they won't make it a priority unless they hear from their constituents.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

linkUrl.text: Campaign for an Independent Public Defense Commission

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Hour Children serves a vulnerable population of mothers and children rejoining the community and reuniting as family.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Communities United for Police Reform (CPR) is an unprecedented campaign to end discriminatory policing practices in New York, bringing together a movement of community members, lawyers, researchers and activists to work for change. The partners in this campaign come from all 5 boroughs, from all walks of life and represent many of those most unfairly targeted by the NYPD. This groundbreaking campaign is fighting for reforms that will promote community safety while ensuring that the NYPD protects and serves all New Yorkers. They are a movement that is here to stay – a campaign that will be a visible, lasting presence on the streets of neighborhoods citywide. They will be in communities and on the streets, educating people about their rights; and in the courts and on the steps of City Hall and the state capitol, demanding change to the NYPD -- until these policies end.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Arab American Association of New York, Audre Lorde Project, Bronx Defenders and many others

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Prisoners’ Rights Project is a leading advocate of humane and constitutional conditions in the New York City jails and State prisons. The Project seeks to dismantle the oppression and racism of the carceral system by protecting the safety and basic human rights of the people who are subjected to it.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.campaignName: Substance Use and Mental Health Program

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Vera’s Substance Use and Mental Health Program (SUMH) conducts applied research to help public officials and community organizations develop empirically driven responses to the substance use and mental health needs of people involved in justice systems. SUMH staff collect and analyze quantitative and qualitative data to examine the interaction between public health and justice systems and evaluate existing programs to understand the experiences of those affected by psychiatric disorders or substance use and policies that prolong their involvement in the justice system.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

linkUrl.text: Substance Use and Mental Health Program

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"IDP engages in targeted litigation, primarily before the federal courts, in support of challenges to deportations and other adverse immigration consequences based on criminal convictions and arrests. By supporting litigants before the Supreme Court and Circuit Courts of Appeals, they seek to create good law through the judiciary to help immigrants remain in the United States with their communities and families.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"This year, SUSU focuses on supporting children’s educational success and wellbeing from early childhood through college. Throughout the month of October, they will share resources, tips, and stories on how to increase visibility and support for children of incarcerated parents, of all ages, in schools.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: The New York Initiative for Children of Incarcerated Parents

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"HIPS promotes the health, rights, and dignity of individuals and communities impacted by sexual exchange and/or drug use due to choice, coercion, or circumstance. HIPS provides compassionate harm reduction services, advocacy, and community engagement that is respectful, non-judgmental, and affirms and honors individual power and agency.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Redemption Campaign is a statewide initiative to safely release thousands of people who pose no public safety risk from Colorado prisons by challenging Governor Polis to use existing clemency powers in new and transformational ways. Their mission is to replace the architecture of mass incarceration with a roadmap to freedom and redemption.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Second Chance Center, Colorado Criminal Justice Reform Coalition, Office of the Colorado State Public Defender, the Powell Project and the ACLU of Colorado

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Youth Justice Coalition (YJC) is working to build a youth, family, and formerly and currently incarcerated people’s movement to challenge America’s addiction to incarceration and race, gender and class discrimination in Los Angeles County’s, California’s and the nation’s juvenile and criminal injustice systems.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Justice Now focuses on the needs of women prisoners. They work on alternative sentencing; document human rights abuses in prison; provide legal services around women's healthcare access, and offer assistance with compassionate release. Serves women in California only.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Free the Block is a campaign to end money bail and pre-trial detention in Miami-Dade County and Tampa. Inspired by campaigns for criminal justice and bail reform happening all over the country, Dream Defenders and other partner organizations are collecting thousands of petition signatures to make the case for adopting alternatives to money bail and pre-trial detention that are far more effective and humane.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Campaign to Rescind Special Order 1(1) is an alliance of different organizations (and, in our case, individuals), each with their own interests, mission and vision, that come together to collaborate and take collective action together toward a common goal(s). We reject all forms of police oppression and any policy that make us all suspects in the eyes of the State. Our vision is the dismantling of government-sanctioned spying and intelligence gathering, in all its multiple forms.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.campaignName: Voices of Youth in Chicago Education (VOYCE)

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Voices of Youth in Chicago Education (VOYCE) is a core Communities United project. VOYCE develops a leadership pipeline of low-income youth who are directly impacted by the school-to-prison pipeline. The VOYCE leadership pipeline works to advance safe and supportive school climates, and promotes the expansion of restorative justice practices and other trauma-informed supports, such as increasing resources for mental health in schools.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Organized Communities Against Deportations (OCAD), Black Youth Project 100 (BYP100), and Mijente have been leading a local campaign urging the city of Chicago expand what it means to be a “Sanctuary City” to protect immigrants and US born people of color, particularly those who are targeted by local police. Exposing and eliminating the gang database has jumped to the top of the agenda this week after it became clear that Mr. Catalan-Ramirez’s targeting by ICE was in part a responsibility of the Chicago police.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Organized Communities Against Deportations (OCAD), Black Youth Project 100 (BYP100), and Mijente

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Lucy Parsons Labs is a charitable Chicago-based collaboration between data scientists, transparency activists, artists, & technologists that sheds light on the intersection of digital rights and on-the-streets issues.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The mission of the Coalition for Police Accountability (“the Coalition” or CPA) is to advocate for accountability of the Oakland Police Department to the community so that the Oakland Police Department operates with equitable, just, constitutional, transparent policies and practices that reflect the values and engender the trust of the community.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: SEIU Local 1021, Faith in Action East Bay, League of Women Voters (Oakland), Wellstone Democratic Renewal Group, NAACP (Oakland chapter), Latino Task Force, Block by Block Organizing Network, and others

nodes.campaignName: The Center for Resilient Individuals, Families and Communities (CRIFC)

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Center for Resilient Individuals, Families and Communities (CRIFC) is committed to the sustainability of healthier communities across the southern region and beyond by employing abolitionist tactics centering folks and their families directly impacted by mass incarceration. Our programming involves social services stabilization for the collective change makers of local, regional and national abolitionist movements, direct action, community organizing apprenticeships and political education, reading circles for children and youth, seasonal micro grants, emergency funds, social services referral, and creating/re-envisioning community services networks. The extension of our mission is to educate, support and organize individuals, families and communities, local, nationally, and internationally around best practices, best tactics, innovative service methods, and social policies which govern the lives we live.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: The Center for Resilient Individuals, Families and Communities (CRIFC)

linkUrl.text: The Center for Resilient Individuals, Families and Communities (CRIFC)

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"They assess and reform fines and fees that have an adverse disproportionate impact on low-income people and communities of color \n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Housed in San Francisco Office of the Treasurer and Tax Collector

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The campaign goals are to end mass incarceration and create jobs. \n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Ella Baker Center; Justice Reinvestment Coalition

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The mission of TOP’S Right2Justice (R2J) Campaign is to end mass incarceration and the criminalization of poverty of Black and Latino people in four of the largest counties in Texas (Harris, Dallas, Bexar and Fort Bend) by creating a justice system that is fair and just.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Girl Scouts Beyond Bars (GSBB) is a unique program that gives girls age 5 through 17 the opportunity to build and maintain relationships with their incarcerated parents. The program also brings together girls whose families have been impacted by incarceration. Their mission is to decrease the effects of parent-child separation and rebuild bonds between parents and children.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Based in marginalized neighborhoods in Charlotte, North Carolina, Detroit, Michigan, and Los Angeles, California, they look at digital data collection and our human rights, work with local communities, community organizations, and social support networks, and show how different data systems impact re-entry, fair housing, public assistance, and community development.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}
{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"rich text","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Grassroots Advocates for Neighborhood Groups & Solutions (GANGS) Coalition's goal is to dismantle systems that increase surveillance, and/or police contact, or enhance punishment based on law enforcement profiling of Black, Latinx and immigrant communities as gang or crew members. Central to eliminating the use of these tools is the redirecting of resources away from the police department and prosecutors and towards harm-reducing, community-based programs that are proven to make neighborhoods safer.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Policing and Social Justice Project @ CUNY

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Bronx Defenders is a public defender nonprofit that is radically transforming how low-income people in the Bronx are represented in the justice system and, in doing so, is transforming the system itself.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Friends Outside has provided services to incarcerated and reentering people,their families, and communities since 1955.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Transportation Equity Caucus is focused on driving transportation policies that advance economic and social equity in America by creating affordable transportation options for all people; ensuring fair access to quality jobs, workforce development, and contracting opportunities ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Reentry Project partners in the Restoring Rights and Opportunities Coalition of Illinois (RROCI), working with Cabrini Green Legal Aid Clinic and Community Renewal Society. RROCI advocates for state policies that remove barriers for people in reentry, including lifetime employment bans and limited access to housing. Heartland Alliance was part of RROCI from 2016 – 2020.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The #NoCopAcademy campaign is an effort supported by over 85 community organizations across Chicago, that want to see $95 million invested in our communities rather than police training grounds.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"For over 30 years, Tenants and Workers United (TWU) has been organizing low-income communities of color -- low-wage workers, immigrants, women, and youth -- to build power so people can become change agents in their own lives by addressing the issues they care about. They advance racial, economic, and social justice by fighting for education, housing, and immigrants' rights. They build community-led campaigns to win change for their community.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Housing Not Handcuffs is a national campaign to stop the criminalization of homelessness, such as making it illegal for people to sit, sleep, and even eat in public places—despite the absence of housing or even shelter, and other basic resources —and to push for effective housing policies that end homelessness.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"A national campaign to stop investments in private equity prison profiteers.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"To create more mechanisms to give people second chances, reunite families, and reduce mass incarceration. FAMM’s Second Chances Agenda includes passing “second look” laws, expanding compassionate release, and using clemency more often.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"A campaign to free incarcerated people in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic. As part of this campaign, advocates in 27 states have helped over 200 incarcerated women submit applications for clemency to their governors","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: National Council for Incarcerated and Formerly Incarcerated Women and Girls; Color of Change

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Positive Women’s Network – USA is a national membership body of women living with HIV and our allies that exists to strengthen the strategic power of all women living with HIV in the United States. Founded in 2008 by 28 diverse women leaders living with HIV, PWN-USA develops a leadership pipeline and policy agenda that applies a gender lens to the domestic HIV epidemic grounded in social justice and human rights.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The campaign supports raising the age of juvenile court to 21 to bring our court system in line with research that shows young adults (people ages 18-21) are more similar to juveniles than adults in terms of criminal offending.




","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Fines and Fees Justice Center; Civil Rights Corps

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"#EndTheException works to pass the Abolition Amendment — introduced by Senator Jeff Merkley (OR) and Representative Nikema Williams (GA-05) — which would eliminate the exception to the 13th ammednment that allows slavery and involuntary servitude to be used as punishment for crime. \n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"R2C is a public awareness initiative that uses value-based communication tactics to inform policymakers, criminal justice stakeholders, and the public about the importance of carrying out the Sixth Amendment’s right to counsel, the ways in which the right to counsel is not being implemented, the roles everyone from law enforcement officers to prosecutors to judges and court managers can play in ensuring that the constitutional right to counsel is upheld, and how to reform the public defense system with low-cost or no-cost policy solutions.


","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Justice Programs Office at American University and many other

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"ACT4JJ advocates for the reauthorization of the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act (JJDPA) and for federal funding for juvenile justice programs and services\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Connect Families Now is a network of prison phone justice campaigns across the country striving to make prison and jail phone calls free.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Work with families impacted by detention and familial seperation to provide support in case management, food assistance, transportation, legal support, employment, spiritual support, and linkage to community support\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Center for Resilient Individuals, Families, and Communities; Movement for Black Lives

linkUrl.text: Center for Resilient Individuals, Families, and Communities

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"CRIFC Summer Micro-grants administers micro grants to be awarded for youth impacted by incarceration (ages 12-23) to start projects in their communities.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Center for Resilient Individuals, Families, and Communities; Movement for Black Lives

linkUrl.text: Center for Resilient Individuals, Families, and Communities

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"A Labor of Love provides fellowships and apprenticeships for Black individuals bailed out through regional efforts, legal fund campaigns, and probation parole campaigns.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Center for Resilient Individuals, Families, and Communities; National Bail Out (NBO); Movement for Black Lives

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"WEGOTUSNOW highlights compelling stories from its Actionists, directly impacted children, young adults, and families from across the United States, so that they can: give in-depth perspectives and insight into the impact of parental separation due to mass incarceration; uplift the concerns and experiences of daughters + sons with incarcerated parents; and amplify the policies & practices that they are advocating for to Keep Families Connected, end mass incarceration and #ProtectOurParents behind bars amid COVID-19.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Challenges the systemic problem of pushout in our nation’s schools and works to dismantle the school-to-prison pipeline. As a national coalition, DSC builds power amongst parents, youth, organizers, advocates and educators to transform their own communities, support alternatives to a culture of zero-tolerance, punishment, criminalization and the dismantling of public schools, and fight for the human right of every young person to a quality education and to be treated with dignity.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: A Black Education Network, Boston Area Youth Organizing Project, Children's Defense Fund NY, COFI/POWER-PAC, Parents Organizing for Public Education, and others

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Multiyear effort to reduce the U.S. jail and prison population by 50% and to combat racial disparities in the criminal justice system.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Youth-centered effort advocating for the creation of new systems, policies, investments, and structures that reimagine life for young people in America, focusing on economic justice and opportunity, justice and safe communities, enviornmental justice, immigration justice, democracy and civic engagement \n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Center for Law and Social Policy (CLASP)

nodes.campaignName: People's Coalition for Safety and Freedom

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"This coalition is focused on addressing the harm caused by the '94 Crime Bill and creating a new vision for safety and freedom, including: (1) a people's process led by the people most harmed by the criminal legal system; (2) transforming the system by dismantling racist and punitive policies; (3) replacing harmful policies with new ones shaped by and for communities \n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Law for Black Lives, Center for Popular Democracy, PolicyLink, The Leadership Conference

linkUrl.text: People's Coalition for Safety and Freedom

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Transportation Equity Caucus is focused on driving transportation policies that advance economic and social equity in America by creating affordable transportation options for all people; ensuring fair access to quality jobs, workforce development, and contracting opportunities \n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Their work is dedicated to creating a democratic society in which Black Chicagoans engaged in the informal economy—activities, enterprises, and jobs not protected by the state—have the resources to change the social and economic conditions affecting their lives.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.campaignName: Power U Center for Social Change

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"They are organizing and developing the leadership of Black and Brown youth and Black women in South Florida so that they may help lead the struggle to liberate all oppressed people.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Power U Center for Social Change

linkUrl.text: Power U Center for Social Change

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Messages Project is a nonprofit organization that enables children of incarcerated parents to maintain and rebuild relationships with their mothers and fathers. Since 1999, The Messages Project has recorded and delivered more than 10,000 video messages from incarcerated parents to their children. Carolyn LeCroy, Founder and CEO of The Messages Project, was named a CNN Hero in 2008 for her efforts and advocacy for these at-risk youth.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.campaignName: Voices of Youth in Chicago Education

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Voices of Youth in Chicago Education (VOYCE) is a youth organizing alliance for education and racial justice led by students of color from across the city of Chicago and Illinois. Formed in 2007, VOYCE focuses on developing a youth leadership pipeline of low-income youth of color to advance safe and supportive school climates and healing-centered approaches to teaching and learning.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"One Love Global's mission is to transform communities so Black children experience justice, peace, healing, opportunity, and abundance.They envision global liberation and reparations where Black people experience radical love of self, community, and planet.\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

nodes.leadOrganization: Black Lives Matter, Movement for Black Lives, Truth, Racial Healing and Transformation

nodes.campaignName: The Fight for the Soul of the Cities

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Fight for the Soul of the Cities is an international vision for urban organizing—focusing on Los Angeles, and from there, to the major cities of the U.S. in solidarity with the cities and people of the Third World. It is the product of 24 years of organizing by the Labor/Community Strategy Center, 20 years of work by our Bus Riders Union, and seven years of work by our Community Rights Campaign.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.campaignName: Families and Friends of Louisiana’s Incarcerated Children

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Their mission is to create a better life for all of Louisiana’s youth, especially those involved in or targeted by the juvenile justice system.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Families and Friends of Louisiana’s Incarcerated Children

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Guided by community perspectives and a wide range of municipal data, WCRJ has crafted an informed and strategic policy proposal to promote equitable public safety in Chicago. The three year plan calls for a series of funding reductions to the Chicago Police Department (CPD), as well as concurrent budget increases to vital social services and public health programs. The proposal also provides for a newly established Community Safety Unit to provide residents with emergency public safety dispatch services, outside of law enforcement.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In far too many communities across Illinois, the response to school safety concerns has been to “harden” schools with additional school resource officers, security guards, metal detectors, surveillance cameras, and other law enforcement strategies. For example, there are school districts all across the state that have more SROs and security guards than social workers and psychologists. This approach has produced severe harm, creating unhealthy learning environments and criminalizing youth all across the state, particularly within communities of color. It has also been ineffective at creating truly safe schools. The safest schools aren’t “hardened” schools; they’re schools in which the developmental needs of all students are being met. Through the Rethinking Safety campaign, VOYCE will continue to build on its success in affecting statewide policy change through SB100, which created groundbreaking reform in schools’ approaches to student discipline, and the 2019 passage of a state grants pilot that advances the Rethinking Safety campaign by creating a framework for school districts to expand resources for mental and behavioral health, restorative justice, and other trauma-informed supports for youth.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Voices of Youth in Chicago Education

linkUrl.text: Voices of Youth in Chicago Education

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Led by students, the Urban Youth Collaborative (UYC) brings together New York City students to fight for real education reform that puts students first. Demanding a high quality education for all students, their young people struggle for social, economic, and racial justice in their schools and communities.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"SpiritHouse uses culture, art and media to support the empowerment and transformation of communities most impacted by poverty, racism, gender inequity, criminalization and mass incarceration; through grassroots programs, cultural organizing and community collaborations. .\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Southern Coalition for Social Justice partners with communities of color and economically disadvantaged communities in the South to defend and advance their political, social, and economic rights through the combination of legal advocacy, research, organizing, and communications.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Rethink’s mission is to support Black youth in becoming thoughtful revolutionary leaders capable of critically rethinking their experiences and taking action to create transformative systemic change.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"PrYSM organizes at the intersections of race, class, gender, and sexual orientation by centering youth, female, queer, and people of color leadership in our campaigns, our organization, and our communities. PrYSM mobilizes queer Southeast Asian youth, families, and allies to build grassroots power and organize collectively for social justice.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Project South is a Southern-based leadership development organization that creates spaces for movement building. They work with communities pushed forward by the struggle– to strengthen leadership and to provide popular political and economic education for personal and social transformation. They build relationships with organizations and networks across the US and global South to inform our local work and to engage in bottom-up movement building for social and economic justice.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The People’s Advocacy Institute (PAI) is a non-profit community resource, training and capacity-building incubator for transformation justice in the South. PAI serves as a vehicle for true democracy, harnessing the collective wisdom of southern communities that have been directly impacted by a divestment from key community systems such as mass criminalization and incarceration and economic inequality. By engaging communities in electoral justice efforts, People's Assemblies, Alternatives to Incarceration Initiatives, and an intentional grassroots process for cultivating ideas and developing solutions PAI, builds community capacity, inspires self-determination and community-driven solutions to violence, punitive legal systems and social injustice facing far too many communities. They believe that community agency is what architects robust systems change and is what is needed to build new institutional power that paves the way for a more just system rooted in restoration, resilience and self-determination. \n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"‍OCAD stands for Organized Communities Against Deportations. They're a group of undocumented, unapologetic, and unafraid organizers building a resistance movement against deportations and the criminalization of immigrants and people of color in Chicago and surrounding areas.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Critical Exposure trains DC youth to harness the power of photography and their own voices to fight for educational equity and social justice. They're creating a new generation of civic leaders who have: the tools to express themselves, the creativity to imagine new solutions to old problems, the belief that youth have the right and ability to fight for those solutions, and the skills to hold communities and public officials accountable. Through campaigns and visual storytelling, Critical Exposure helps students raise their voices in conversations about education policies and build the public support and political will needed to address the issues they face.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Care Not Cops Portland (CNC) was founded in 2017 to reduce the violence of policing and build up community care. CNC works to reduce the Portland Police Bureau budget (PPB) and advocate for redirecting public resources to community alternatives and programs that address harm and build strong, thriving communities.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Voices Of Community Activists & Leaders (VOCAL-NY) is a statewide grassroots membership organization that builds power among low-income people affected by HIV/AIDS, the drug war, mass incarceration, and homelessness in order to create healthy and just communities. We accomplish this through community organizing, leadership development, advocacy, direct services, participatory research and direct action.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Center for Community Alternatives (CCA), founded in 1981, is a leader in community-based alternatives to incarceration and policy advocacy to reduce reliance on incarceration. They provide direct services to communities in New York City, Syracuse, and Rochester, engaging approximately 2,500 youth and adults annually who would otherwise be incarcerated. The great majority of their participants are African American or Latino/a and come from poor or low-income communities.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"They serve as a strategic partner for nonprofit organizations, coalitions, and networks at the forefront of movements organizing for a more just, equitable, and free South. Their work catalyzes success for movements and expands democratic opportunities for people affected by injustice. The victories they achieve together accelerate national change.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The Chicago Community Bond Fund (CCBF) pays bond for people charged with crimes in Cook County, Illinois. Through a revolving fund, CCBF supports individuals whose communities cannot afford to pay the bonds themselves and who have been impacted by structural violence. Inability to pay bond results in higher rates of conviction, longer sentences, loss of housing and jobs, separation of families, and lost custody of children. By paying bond, CCBF restores the presumption of innocence before trial and enables recipients to remain free while fighting their cases. CCBF also engages in public education about the role of bond in the criminal legal system and advocates for the abolition of money bond. CCBF is committed to long-term relationship building and organizing with people most directly impacted by criminalization and policing.\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Founded by and for formerly incarcerated and marginalized Black people in Chicago, Equity and Transformation (EAT) strives to uplift the faces, voices, and power of individuals that operate within the informal economy. These are the bucket boys who we pass on the way to the train every day, the DVD bootlegger at your local barber shop, the person selling loose cigarettes at two for a dollar in front of the local liquor store, and the trans and cisgender commercial sex workers in our communities.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"A project of Tides Advocacy, is leading a movement to decarcerate the largest jail population in the United States–the LA County jail system–by reducing the power and scope of the judiciary, law enforcement and the legal injustice system. They do this by fighting for a fair & transparent pretrial process, state & local budgets that reflect our values, life-affirming alternatives to incarceration, and judicial accountability.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Essie Justice Group is a nonprofit organization of women with incarcerated loved ones taking on the rampant injustices created by mass incarceration. Their award-winning Healing to Advocacy Model brings women together to heal, build collective power, and drive social change. They are building a membership of fierce advocates for race and gender justice — including Black and Latinx women, formerly and currently incarcerated women, transgender women, and gender non-conforming people.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Dignity and Power Now (DPN) is a Los Angeles based grassroots organization founded in 2012 that fights for the dignity and power of all incarcerated people, their families, and communities. Their mission is to build a Black and Brown led abolitionist movement rooted in community power towards the goal of achieving transformative justice and healing justice for all incarcerated people, their families, and communities.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The Detroit Justice Center (DJC) is a non-profit law firm working alongside communities to create economic opportunities, transform the justice system, and promote equitable and just cities.\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"They are community lawyers. In our legal work we collaborate closely with community organizers and grassroots groups in low-income communities of color because we believe that a more democratic, more just and more equal society can only truly come about through grassroots organizing and social movement. They are a part of that social movement in South Florida and strive to support organizing through our varied and often innovative legal work.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Today, the Dream Defenders is organizing Black and Brown youth to build power in our communities to advance a new vision they have for the state. Their agenda is called the Freedom Papers. Through it, they are advancing their vision of safety and security – away from prisons, deportation, and war – and towards healthcare, housing, jobs and movement for all.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"They Report to You empowers Oregonians to improve our criminal justice system by redefining the role of district attorneys, increasing voter engagement with these important elected positions, and advocating for reforms that appropriately balance the enormous power and discretion of prosecutors.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Sentencing Project promotes effective and humane responses to crime that minimize imprisonment and criminalization of youth and adults by promoting racial, ethnic, economic, and gender justice.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Nearly six million kids in America have experienced losing a parent to prison or jail at some point in their lives. Foreverfamily works to ensure that, no matter what the circumstances, all children have the opportunity to be surrounded by the love of family.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The mission of AFOI is to provide opportunities for regular, meaningful visitation, referrals to community resources, and other services that help families cope with incarceration and prepare for release and reunification. They strive to prevent the breakdown of relationships among inmates and their families by providing regular, meaningful visitation, support, referrals and education services.  Their programs help families and loved ones throughout the period of incarceration and also prepare families for a successful transition when the inmate is released from prison back into our community. Assisting Families of Inmates is one of only a handful of such programs to provide these services in Virginia and across the United States.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"They work to inform solutions to crime and safety challenges in the interests of promoting effectiveness in justice systems and operations; addressing the harms of victimization and justice system involvement; reducing racial and other inequities; strengthening community-led approaches to safety; and promoting justice, dignity, and well-being for all. They conduct objective, rigorous, interdisciplinary research, evaluation, and policy analysis and deliver data-driven recommendations, training, and technical assistance. In carrying out their research, they seek to center the voices, experiences, and perspectives of the people, practitioners, and communities most affected by crime and the criminal justice system.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"No Exceptions Prison Collective is a grassroots initiative in Nashville, TN, dedicated to ending carceral enslavement by advocating that no exceptions be made to the abolition of slavery. They were founded and are led by individuals directly impacted by carceral slavery – both insiders (prisoners) and free world folk.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Close the Workhouse campaign aims to attack mass incarceration, without legitimizing or justifying the continued caging of people as punishment. They call for the closure of the Medium Security Institute, better known in St. Louis as the Workhouse, an end to wealth based pretrial detention, and the reinvestment of the money used to cage poor people and Black people into rebuilding the most impacted neighborhoods in this region.  \n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Action St. Louis, ArchCity Defenders, and Bail Project St. Louis.

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"For the past 5 years, APTP’s Defund OPD committee has been leading the call to defund the police and invest in communities. Their work has grown into the Defund Police Coalition with 13 BIPOC-led grassroots organizations* dedicated to refunding, restoring, and reimagining Oakland.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The Bettering Our School System campaign aims to: End the criminalization of Black and Brown students in the Oakland Unified School District, Invest in alternative models for school safety (end reliance on police), Restructure the current policies and practices within OUSD that don’t take a restorative justice approach to student discipline and that perpetuate the school to prison pipeline.


","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

nodes.campaignName: North Carolina Statewide Police Accountability Network (NC SPAN)

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"NC SPAN is building a  statewide alliance that will build inter-sectional people power that seeks to move from a police state and dismantle police departments power by creating more police accountability, police free zones, and by build community, education, and alternate systems.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: North Carolina Black Leadership and Organizing Collective

linkUrl.text: North Carolina Statewide Police Accountability Network (NC SPAN)

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"This campaign advocates for the passage of the Community Safety and Fair Sentencing Act, which would allow judges to depart from the mandatory minimum sentence for certain second and subsequent drug offenders in order to design a punishment that truly fits the crime. \n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"As the United States moves away from the criminalization of cannabis, giving rise to a major new industry, there remains the fundamental injustice inflicted upon those who have suffered criminal convictions and the consequences of those convictions. Last Prisoner Project utilizes a three-pronged approach to securing FULL freedom for the communities we serve. Through intervention, advocacy, and awareness campaigns the Last Prisoner Project works to redress the past and continuing harms of these unjust laws and policies.\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"This coalition is working towards and LA county where the well-being and health of the whole community is prioritized over incarceration.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Californians United for Responsible Budget (CURB), Color of Change, Critical Resistance Los Angeles, Dignity and Power Now, Essie Justice Group, Frontline Wellness Network, Gender Justice LA, La Defensa, Million Dollar Hoods and others

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The People’s Budget LA is a coalition led by Black Lives Matter LA  demanding a city budget that invests in the wellbeing of communities with priority on supporting the underserved and marginalized.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Georgia Justice Project strengthens their community by demonstrating a better way to represent and support individuals in the criminal justice system and reduce barriers to reentry. GJP promotes innovative change through direct legal representation, policy advocacy, education and coalition building.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Solutions Not Punishment Collaborative is a Black, Trans-led, broad based abolitionist collaborative to restore an Atlanta where every person has the opportunity to grow and thrive without facing barriers, especially from the Criminal Justice System. \n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Debt Free Justice California (DFJC) is a multi-regional California-based coalition focused on putting a stop to the unfair ways the criminal legal system drains wealth from vulnerable communities. The coalition is comprised of legal advocates, policy experts, and most importantly movement building organizations led by impacted people.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: East Bay Community Law Center, ACLU of Southern California

nodes.campaignName: Better Justice Florida - Florida Campaign for Criminal Justice Reform

campaignDescription.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The Florida Campaign for Criminal Justice Reform is dedicated to ending over-incarceration and racial disparities in Florida’s criminal justice system through data-driven, proven approaches that will save taxpayer money, keep families intact, and make Florida communities safer by maintaining human dignity, and prioritizing rehabilitation, treatment, and alternatives to incarceration.\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

nodes.leadOrganization: Florida Campaign for Criminal Justice Reform (supported by SPLC, ACLU FL, Souther Legal Counsel, Florida Council of Churches, Florida Cares Charity)

linkUrl.text: Better Justice Florida - Florida Campaign for Criminal Justice Reform

campaignDescription.raw:
{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Blueprint is the product of more than a year of research and outreach 
to stakeholders and practitioners across California. The Blueprint offers a
framework of principles and practices that local leaders can use to advance
shared safety strategies.

","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Alliance for Safety and Justice, Californians for Safety and Justice

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Close the Jail ATL Campaign is a ground breaking, local campaign dedicated to divesting from Atlanta’s unjust criminal legal system and investing in their communities by closing the extra City Jail (ACDC), repurposing the facility into a Center for Wellness & Freedom, and reallocating the $32.5 million dollars spent annually to services and supports which help people thrive.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Women on the Rise, The Racial Justice Action Center

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Puente launched this campaign as a result of the ongoing advocacy they do for immigrants and incarcerated individuals. COVID-19 poses a specific threat to those incarcerated or in detention; the lack of personal protective equipment combined with the inability to social distance makes these centers petri dishes for the virus. LGBTQ migrants are at a greater risk of exposure due to discrimination and harassment.\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The campaign goals are to work to reduce the size and impact of the punishment system through an ongoing multimedia storytelling and public education initiative led by incarcerated, formerly incarcerated, convicted people and their loved ones\n\n","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"#CopsOuttaCampus is a youth-led (ages 13-18) campaign that centers young people to lead the shut down of the school to prison/deportation pipeline and boost investments in student-defined safety and wellness in Arizona schools. They facilitate youth leadership and accountability in our schools, and they fight for the resources that they want through social media, grassroots organizing, and advocacy.\n\n","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"This campaign, that we began in 2014, focuses on 6 structural and interrelated demands—all of which can be carried out by the board of directors of the Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority—MTA.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The Workers Center for Racial Justice is a grassroots organization fighting for Black Liberation and a fair and inclusive society that benefits all people.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Signed into law in January 2014, the Community Safety Act has brought groundbreaking reform to the NYPD and has paved the way for future reforms efforts to bring about substantive change to policing in NYC. The passage of the CSA was a historic victory in the movement for police accountability and would not have been possible without the leadership of community groups and advocates, elected officials, and the thousands of individuals who signed petitions, mobilized to rallies, talked to their neighbors, and called their local City Council Members.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

nodes.leadOrganization: Desis Rising Up and Moving (DRUM), Communities united for Police Reform (CPR), Brennan Center, and Muslim American Civil Liberties Coalition (MACLC)

campaignDescription.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Incarceration can strain family ties to the breaking point. Prison Fellowship Angel Tree provides an opportunity for local congregations to extend the hope of the Gospel and enfold Angel Tree families into church life through delivering Christmas gifts on behalf of incarcerated parents, sending kids to summer camp, facilitating one-day sports camps, and more.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}
